speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I will start with a recap of our discussions, including our assessment of the outlook for the economy and the judgments we made about our interest rate policy and our balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I will cover the decisions we made today as well as our ongoing discussions of matters on which we expect to make decisions in coming meetings.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: My colleagues and I have one overarching goal: to sustain the economic expansion, with a strong job market and stable prices, for the benefit of the American people.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The U.S. economy is in a good place, and we will continue to use our monetary policy tools to help keep it there.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The jobs picture continues to be strong, with the unemployment rate near historic lows and with stronger wage gains.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Inflation remains near our 2 percent goal.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We continue to expect that the American economy will grow at a solid pace in 2019, although likely slower than the very strong pace of 2018.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We believe that our current policy stance is appropriate at this time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Despite this positive outlook, over the past few months we have seen some crosscurrents and conflicting signals about the outlook.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Growth has slowed in some major foreign economies, particularly in China and Europe.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: There is elevated uncertainty around several unresolved government policy issues, including Brexit, ongoing trade negotiations, and the effects from the partial government shutdown in the United States.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Financial conditions tightened considerably late in 2018 and remain less supportive of growth than they were earlier in 2018.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And, while most of the incoming domestic economic data have been solid, some surveys of business and consumer sentiment have moved lower, giving reason for caution.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We always emphasize that our policies are data dependent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In other words, as economic conditions and the outlook evolve, we take that new information into account in setting our policies.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We are now facing a somewhat contradictory picture of generally strong U.S. macroeconomic performance alongside growing evidence of crosscurrents.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: At such times, common-sense risk management suggests patiently awaiting greater clarity—an approach that has served policymakers well in the past.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: With that in mind, I’d like to spell out how the Federal Open Market Committee has been thinking about these issues.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: At our December meeting, we noted the solid outlook for steady growth, vigorous job creation, and price stability.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We also stressed that the extent and timing of any rate increases were uncertain and would depend on incoming data and the evolving outlook.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We therefore said that we would be paying close attention to global economic and financial developments and assessing their implications for the economic outlook.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Today the FOMC decided that the cumulative effects of those developments over the last several months warrant a patient, wait-and-see approach regarding future policy changes.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In particular, our statement today says, “In light of global economic and financial developments and muted inflation pressures, the Committee will be patient as it determines what future adjustments to the target range for the federal funds rate may be appropriate.” This change was not driven by a major shift in the baseline outlook for the economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Like many forecasters, we still see “sustained expansion of economic activity, strong labor market conditions, and inflation near .

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: 2 percent” as the likeliest case.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But the crosscurrents I mentioned suggest the risk of a less favorable outlook.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In addition, the case for raising rates has weakened somewhat.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The traditional case for rate increases is to protect the economy from risks that arise when rates are too low for too long, particularly the risk of too-high inflation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Over the past few months, that risk appears to have diminished.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Inflation readings have been muted, and the recent drop in oil prices is likely to push headline inflation lower still in coming months.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Further, as we noted in our postmeeting statement, while survey-based measures of inflation expectations have been stable, financial market measures of inflation compensation have moved lower.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Similarly, the balance—the risk of financial imbalances appears to have receded, as a number of indicators that showed elevated levels of financial risk appetite last fall have moved closer to historical norms.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In this environment, we believe we can best support the economy by being patient in evaluating the outlook before making any future adjustment to policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Let me now turn to balance sheet normalization.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Over its past three meetings, the FOMC has held in-depth discussions on the final stages of this process.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Today we made some important progress in clarifying the path forward, as summarized in the Statement Regarding Monetary Policy Implementation and Balance Sheet Normalization that we released with today’s FOMC statement.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The Committee made the fundamental decision today to continue indefinitely using our current operating procedure for implementing monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: That is, we will continue to use our administered rates to control the policy rate with an ample supply of reserves so that active management of reserves is not required.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: This is often called a “floor system” or an “abundant reserves system.” Under the current set of operating procedures, as outlined in the implementation note released today, this means that the federal funds rate, our active policy tool, is held within its target range by appropriately setting the Federal Reserve’s administered rates of interest on reserves, as well as the offer rate on the overnight reverse repo facility, without managing the supply of reserves actively.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: As the minutes of our recent discussions have indicated, the FOMC strongly believes that this approach provides good control of short-term money market rates in a variety of market conditions and effective transmission of those rates to broader financial conditions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Settling this central question clears the way for the FOMC to address a number of further questions regarding the remaining stages of balance sheet normalization.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The decision to retain our current operating procedure means that, after allowing for currency in circulation, the ultimate size of our balance sheet will be driven principally by financial institutions’ demand for reserves, plus a buffer so that fluctuations in reserve demand do not require us to make frequent sizable market interventions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Estimates of the level of reserve demand are quite uncertain, but we know that this demand in the post-crisis environment is far larger than before.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Higher reserve holdings are an important part of the stronger liquidity position that financial institutions must now hold.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Moreover, based on surveys and market intelligence, current estimates of reserve demand are considerably higher than estimates of a year or so ago.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The implication is that the normalization of the size of the portfolio will be completed sooner, and with a larger balance sheet, than in previous estimates.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In light of these estimates and the substantial progress we have made in reducing reserves, the Committee is now evaluating the appropriate timing for the end of balance sheet runoff.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: This decision will likely be part of a plan for gradually reaching our ultimate balance sheet goals while minimizing risks to achieving our dual-mandate objectives and avoiding unnecessary market disruption.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We will be finalizing these plans at coming meetings.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The process of balance sheet normalization is unprecedented.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Throughout this process we’ve attempted to lay out our plans well in advance, and we’ve been willing to make changes as we learn more about the process.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The implementation and normalization statement released today is intended to provide some additional clarity regarding the conditions under which we might adjust our plans.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The statement makes three points: First, as we’ve long emphasized, the federal funds rate is our active monetary policy tool.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Second, as far as the particular details of normalization are concerned, we will not hesitate to make changes in light of economic and financial developments.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: This does not mean that we would use the balance sheet as an active tool, but occasional changes could be warranted.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Third, we repeat a sentence of the normalization principles we adopted in June of 2017.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: While the federal funds rate would remain our active tool of policy in a wide range of scenarios, we recognize that the economy could again present conditions in which federal funds rate policy is not sufficient.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In those cases, the FOMC would be prepared to use its full range of tools, including balance sheet policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Times of economic uncertainty put a premium on the clarity and predictability of FOMC policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We are committed to clearly explaining what we are doing and why we’re doing it, both regarding the path of rates and also regarding management of the balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We believe that this transparency is how we can best contribute to macroeconomic stability.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I’ll be glad to take your questions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We think that our policy is at the appropriate point right now.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We think our policy stance is appropriate right now.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We do.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We also know that our policy rate is now in the range of the Committee’s estimates of neutral.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we’ll be—again, we think our policy stance is appropriate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We had an extensive discussion of the baseline and also of the risks to the baseline, and the risks are, of course, the fact that financial conditions have tightened, that global growth has slowed, as well as some, let’s say, government-related risks like Brexit and trade discussions, and also the effects and ultimate disposition of the shutdown.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we looked at—we look at those, and the way we think of it is that policy—we will use our policy, and we have, to offset risks to the baseline.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we view the baseline as still solid, and part of that is the way we adjusted our baseline to address those risks.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So that’s the way we’re thinking about that now.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, generally speaking, we think the outlook is favorable, and we think that these crosscurrents that I referred to—these risks—are going to be with us for a while.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We think our stance is appropriate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We think there’s no pressing need to change our policy stance and no need to rush to judgment there.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I would say that we’ll be looking at a full range of data, and that will include inflation data.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It will include all data relevant to our dual mandate of stable prices and maximum employment.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Remember that our inflation objective is a symmetric one, meaning that we are—we’re always trying to get to 2 percent, and we don’t look at—we look at inflation equally on both sides.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So I can’t get into specific hypotheticals, but I do believe that we have a symmetric objective, and I believe we’ll act that way.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I’m just going to say that the—it’s going to depend entirely on the data.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We’re not making a judgment.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We don’t have a strong prior.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We will be—we will patiently wait and let the data clarify.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Some of the crosscurrents that I refer to may be with us for a while, and I think we’ll be looking at seeing those clear up as it relates to—as they relate to the outlook for the U.S. and that will be an important aspect as well.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, it’s really hard to speak about generalities.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We’ll be looking at everything, but I do think that, you know, muted inflation pressures—you know, you would want—I would want to see a need for further rate increases, and, for me, a big part of that would be inflation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It wouldn’t be the only thing, but it would certainly be important.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Okay.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So today I’m here to talk about decisions and also discussions about decisions that haven’t been made.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we’re talking about the latter thing, which is discussions, and so I can’t get ahead of where decisions are.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But so the Committee is—what we’re looking to do is create a whole plan that will bring us to our goal, our longer-run goal, which is a balance sheet no larger than it needs to be for us to efficiently conduct—efficiently and effectively conduct monetary policy, but to do so in a way that doesn’t put our goals at risk or result in unnecessary market turmoil.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So there are a lot of pieces to that, and we’ve learned over time that it’s—when making these—when designing these plans, like, for example, the original normalization plan, it’s good to take your time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Let the best ideas rise to the top.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Let them stand the test of time and argument and then move when you’re really comfortable with what you’ve got and when you feel you can communicate it clearly.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So I don’t want to get ahead of that process today.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But—so we’ve discussed—there are a number of pieces to that puzzle.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: There are several different pieces to them, and I think they’re coming—and I’m very pleased with the progress that we’ve made, and, you know, the piece that you mentioned is something that is in those discussions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: That’s the first question.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I’m not going to give our estimate or ratify anybody else’s estimate of what the equilibrium balance sheet is here today.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: There are estimates out there, but I’m not at a point today where I’m going to be giving out numbers on that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But there are estimates, and I think they’re consistent with what I said, broadly speaking.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Yes, it’s—so, again, we haven’t made any decisions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: There no decisions have been made.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: There are different pieces of the thing, and that is in the discussion as one of many pieces that is in the discussion.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And that was reflected in the last minutes, actually.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: These are great questions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Let me say that the question of the ultimate composition of our balance sheet in the longer run is a very important one, and it’s one that we see ourselves as coming to, you know, fairly soon, as in, in coming meetings.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It won’t be the first thing we work on, but it will be one of the first things that we try to resolve.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We had discussions at one of the last two meetings on this, and we haven’t come to a judgment on that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And, you know, I wouldn’t comment beyond saying that we understand that’s a key question, and there are, you know, there are issues to be decided.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: There are benefits and costs to doing—to taking different approaches, and I wouldn’t want to prejudge them today.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I’d point to a couple of things.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: First, the narrative of slowing global growth continues, if you will.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The incoming data have shown more of that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We’ve seen that both in China and in Western Europe, and so that’s an important—that has important implications for us, and that story has—let’s just say it continues.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And, in addition—I mean, I think important—possibly less important now—probably less important now, but—has been the shutdown, which will leave some sort of imprint on first- quarter GDP.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We don’t know the ultimate resolution of it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: If that’s all there is, and the shutdown is gone and there isn’t another shutdown, then we’ll get most of that back in the second period—second quarter.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So those things—in addition, you know, you have to look back.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Financial conditions began to tighten in the fourth quarter.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And they now have persisted and remain tighter—significantly tighter, let’s say—than they were, and that’s something that we have to take into account as well.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So that’s where we are.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, patience—I think we’re going to know in hindsight, because the length of this patient period is going to depend entirely on incoming data and its implications for the outlook.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So that’s going to be—so it’s hard to say, you know, it’s hard to think of what to call it at this point or how to label it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So really, your second question is about how do we think about financial conditions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And I would say this: We think about a broad range of financial conditions, not just one or two things.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, it’s interest rates, it’s risk spreads, it’s currency, it’s the stock market, it’s credit availability, it’s many, many factors.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And what matters for financial conditions is, when there are changes and those changes are sustained for a period of time, then they become important for us because they have important macroeconomic implications.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So that’s how we think about it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we don’t react to, you know, to most things that happen in the financial markets.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But when we see a sustained change in financial conditions, then that’s something that has to play into our thinking.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In fact, our policy works through changing financial conditions, so it’s sort of the essence of what we do.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Right.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, on the first question, I can—we don’t comment on individual investigations or whether they’re happening.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I will say that we take our enforcement powers very seriously, and we put them to work when we feel it’s justified.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In terms of real-time payments, it’s something we’re very actively working on.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: As you obviously know, we have some proposals out, and we’re considering them.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, the thing is, it’s very important in that space to consult with the full range of market participants and interest groups, consumer groups, and we’ve done that, as I’m sure you know, over a period of years.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We don’t have plenary authority to just do things, for the most part, in the payment space.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We’ve been more of a convener, bringing industry and the public—public interest groups—and all those groups around the table.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And we’ve—I think we’ve played a constructive role in that respect, and I believe that will continue.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So what we care about—and, really, the only thing we care about at the Fed—is doing our job for the American people and using our tools appropriately.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So that’s very strongly our culture.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I think anyone who knows the Fed or who has worked at the Fed would recognize that description.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we’re always going to do what we think is the right thing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We’re never going to take political considerations into account or discuss them as part of our work.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, we’re human.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We make mistakes.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But we’re not going to make mistakes of character or integrity.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And I would want the public to know that, and I would want them to see that in our actions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I guess the sense of your question is that we could be in a situation in the future—we hope not, but—we could be in a situation where we’d like to cut rates more than we can effectively, and we hit the zero lower bound.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We don’t think anything like that is in the cards.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Now, there’s no reason to think that it would be.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But as we said in today’s release, if that happens, then we’ll use the full range of our tools, and that includes the balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But we would use it after using our conventional tools, which would be the interest rate and forward guidance about the interest rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Yes.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: There would be room to do substantially more.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Right.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So let me give you the economic side of it first—is that, even with a fairly long shutdown, as long as that’s the end of it and everyone gets their backpay—except the contractors, I guess, the private-sector contractors, but—some people get their backpay, then the lost GDP will be regained in the second quarter.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So that’s that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I would say that the—you know, we all see the suffering and the heartbreak and all the pain people go through.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I see, you know, federal employees doing their work, and I’m, you know, really grateful they did.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I mean, to be doing your work while you’re not getting paid, it’s something we should all be grateful for.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: As I mentioned, there wouldn’t be if there isn’t another shutdown.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: If there were going to be a permanent effect or a lasting effect, let’s say, it would be from a longer shutdown or perhaps a second shutdown, and that would be through the channel of a loss of confidence in our ability to make policy in the United States.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: That would be the channel.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And I think that was something that we and many others were worried about as there was talk of an even longer shutdown.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In terms of ideas for not having more shutdowns, I know Congress is actually looking at some of those, so I think that could be a profitable thing to explore.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, trade—you sound like you’re an avid reader of the Beige Book, and that’s great—the trade, as you will know, then—trade has been a big feature in the Beige Book for some time now.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The Beige Book is a collection of all of our—of the comments that our Reserve Bank presidents get from their Districts.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s incredibly valuable, because you’re getting actual reports from people who are on the line.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And there have been real concerns about trade right along the line, both in terms of availability of materials and costs and retaliation and that kind of thing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So that’s been a concern.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I would say the longer-term concern, though, is the negotiations that are going on.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: If they linger, then there could be more and more uncertainty, and you worry over time that that could have an effect on business confidence.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So far, the actual amount of tariffs that have been applied both here and in China is not enough to have material effects on GDP either here or in China.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So the concern is more a longer—for me—a longer, drawn-out set of negotiations back and forth, which could result in sapping business confidence.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Uncertainty is not the friend of business.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, we did—we’ve called out corporate debt as a risk—more of a macroeconomic risk, I think, than a financial stability risk, the sense of that being that if you have companies that are highly levered and we do go into a downturn, they’re going to be less able to weather that and keep serving their customers and, you know, may have to do layoffs and things like that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So they can amplify, in effect, a negative downturn.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we watch that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We also watch carefully for the exposure of the financial system to these companies.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: In other words, banks are arranging a lot of these loans.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we monitor those risks very carefully.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And, frankly, the banks monitor them much better with our support and help than they did before the crisis.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So it’s a concern.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s something that we’re watching.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Of course, you know, November, December, and January were much slower months for those sorts of things.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But, you know, it’ll be something that we’re always paying close attention to.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, I would point to all the continuity here.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, the thing we did on the balance sheet is something we’ve been working on for, frankly, years—the thing we announced today.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And so we’re providing clarity there.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I think that’s a constructive thing to do.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: My—honestly—only motivation is to do the right thing for the economy and for the American people—that’s it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And this situation, I think, calls for patience—I think it does.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And it’s just the stance of policy we think is appropriate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We see these uncertainties, and we see a time when we can afford to—we have the luxury of being able to wait and watch, and that’s what we’re planning to do.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And I think it’s the right thing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I feel strongly that it is.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I’m not going to be able to help you much on that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Those are great questions, and those are questions that are, you know, that our great supervisory people are looking at.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I think we’re open to these ideas, but I don’t have any news for you on that today.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, Steve, it’s certainly possible.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Ultimately, though, you know, a strong global economy is good for us.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We export to these countries.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We trade with these countries.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I mean, part of the story of 2017, for example, was that European growth kept coming in stronger and stronger, and that meant the euro was strong, and that supported our exports.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, ultimately, I think we benefit from having strong growth abroad, although you point to an interesting case.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, first, it is important—we don’t do fiscal policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We don’t advise the government or Congress on fiscal policy, so I’ll limit myself to more high-level comments and say that it is not a secret—it is a long-known fact that the U.S. federal government budget is on an unsustainable path, and that needs to be addressed.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And that is driven principally by the combination of health-care costs—really, due to our health-care delivery system—and the aging of the population.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And there’s no time like now—when the economy is healthy, growing, people are working—to go after that problem.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Ultimately, we will have to.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We don’t have a forecast.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We don’t forecast those things.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I have no reason to doubt CBO’s numbers on this.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I haven’t actually looked at that report, but my general experience with them is that it’s a professional outfit.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, you know, first of all, our—the work that we do relates more to the medium term rather than the long term.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And so I don’t see this, in particular, as a threat to this business cycle or to the economy this year.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It’s more in the longer run, we’ll be spending all of our money on paying interest and not on the things that we really need to be doing for future generations and for our own generation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So it’s a serious problem, but it’s not a problem that is something that either helps or prevents the Fed from doing our job today.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So the range of estimates on the Committee starts at 2½ percent, and that’s kind of roughly where we currently are.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And as I’ve said a couple of times, when you get to that range—you know that we can’t directly observe the neutral rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We only know it by its works.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And so we have to put aside our own priors of what that rate might be and let the data speak to us.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we can do that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We’re in the range.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: There are a number of Committee members who are, you know, right around that range.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And I think we’re watching to see.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We don’t—I don’t—again, I think that our policy stance today is appropriate for the state of the economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: That’s my feeling.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We’re going to be watching data to see whether that’s right, and we’re also going to be watching data to see how these crosscurrents resolve themselves and how the U.S. economy performs this year.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we’ve been monitoring the Brexit situation very carefully for a long time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And for us, that starts with U.S. financial institutions that have a presence either in the U.K. or in the EU or both.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we have worked with those institutions alongside U.K. and EU regulators to assure ourselves that those firms have plans and have liquidity and have all of the things they will need to deal with the full range of Brexit outcomes.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So we’ve done a lot of work on that, and, generally speaking—again, a lot of work has been done—we have to be humble and say that this is an unprecedented event.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But that’s the financial system aspect of it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: If there is a hard Brexit, then that would very likely involve disruptions both to the continental economy and certainly to the U.K. economy, and we would feel that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The question for us—it wouldn’t be a huge first-order thing, the economic effects, unless you saw financial disruptions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So, if you saw financial turmoil and that kind of thing, that would be the way it would reach us.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I would expect that we would feel some of this, and it’s very hard to have great confidence that you know what that would be.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But it would be something—probably not material to our economy, but it’s something we’ll be watching very carefully and certainly hoping that there is a resolution short of a hard Brexit.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Let me be clear.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I don’t know that demand for reserves has risen over the past years.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I think our understanding of demand for reserves—remember that the banks have more reserves than they need.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Reserves are still quite abundant.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And so our understanding, really, of the distribution of reserves and how much will be needed has moved up over the past year.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And then there would be a buffer on top of that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And then we would want to be—we would want to have a buffer, as I mentioned in my remarks, because we want to be operating in an abundant reserves regime where we operate through our administered rates.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: If you operate too close to that point of scarcity, then you wind up having to have these big, ongoing interventions in the market.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We don’t want the Fed to have a, you know, a large ongoing presence in the market around this.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We’d rather just, you know—in managing the federal funds rate, we’d rather have it set by our administered rates.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So that implies you’d want to be a bit above what that equilibrium demand for reserves is.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And, again, there’s no cookbook here, there’s no playbook.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: No one really knows.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: The only way you can figure it out is by surveying people and market intelligence and then, ultimately, by approaching that point quite carefully.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We don’t take—you know, we don’t think we have a precise understanding of this at all.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I want to be clear about that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: These estimates are fairly uncertain.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So if you think that the level of demand for reserves is here [gesturing with hands together, in the middle], all you can say is, it’s probably somewhere in this range [gesturing with hands apart, equidistant from the middle].

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: If banks want to use reserves for a good and sufficient reason—which is to say, to hold liquidity as we require them to do to meet the liquidity coverage ratio, to meet their resolution requirements and resolution planning—we’re not going to discourage them from holding them.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: They are, in fact, a very safe asset—in a way, the safest asset.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And we want the banks to be safe and sound.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We didn’t create the reserves, you know, with that in mind, but, you know, since—in the post-crisis, you know, regulatory regime, we have brand-new and quite substantial liquidity requirements, which are very good and which have great public benefit.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So it’s not a bad thing that banks hold onto these reserves or another safe asset.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We don’t—we’re not encouraging them to hold reserves instead of Treasuries.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Treasuries or reserves are roughly equivalent for this purpose.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I would say that, you know, our mandate is maximum employment and stable prices, and that’s about, you know, hard, real-side economic data.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We—as I mentioned earlier, we—our tool, you know, our interest rate tool operates on the economy through financial conditions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So financial conditions matter, and they matter in the way that I suggested earlier—which is to say, broad financial conditions changing over a sustained period—that has implications for the macroeconomy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: It does.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So if you lower interest rates and they stay low, every borrower in the country ultimately has a lower interest rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: That’ll have an effect on—over time, an effect on the economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: But, again, the entire focus we have is on maximum employment and stable prices, not on any particular financial market or financial conditions generally.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: You know, I’ll quickly go back—in 2017, we were—in designing the normalization plan, we were concerned at not having two active tools of policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: We learned during the taper tantrum, frankly, in 2013 that was—that would be confusing to markets.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So what we did was we set up the normalization of the balance sheet in a way that was very transparent so that you could look and know really, certainly as to Treasuries, pretty much the exact amounts and the timing in which we would be returning these assets to private hands.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: And we put that out there very publicly and in the hope that it would be priced in and understood, and that then we could put the balance sheet on the side and have interest rates be the active tool of policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: So that went along that way very well, and I think that division of labor was a good one for our policy and for the benefit of the country.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: I think that there’s—I think the market is now looking for more clarity around that, and I think we’ll be providing it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: That’s what’s happened.

speaker: CHAIRMAN POWELL
sentence: Thanks very much.
